result.markdown:
--- title: An introduction to R subtitle: https://bit.ly/3ZRsbnA author: - name: Camilo G. email: ca.garcia2@uniandes.edu.co - name: Alejandro C. email: a.castellanoss@uniandes.edu.co - name: Angie T. email: am.tovar11@uniandes.edu.co format: revealjs: footer: | BIOL2205 - Inferencia e Informática - Uniandes standalone: true preview-links: auto center: true slide-number: true fig-align: center code-line-numbers: false overview: true code-link: true code-annotations: hover highlight-style: ayu df-print: paged scrollable: true #smaller: false theme: ../theme.scss --- ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/theme-set_cff0438936d52e94082e747b8229899a'} ::: # R and Rstudio ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ![R console](figs/r-fig.png){fig-align="center"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ![Rstudio IDE](figs/rstudio-fig.png) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ![An script example](figs/script-fig.png) # Rmarkdown and Dynamic Documents {.smaller} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ The YAML block ``` r --- title: ”My fancy title" author: "Camilo García" format: html date: 2022-10-05 --- ``` . . . Simple text (in Markdown) ``` r # Introduction This is **Bold** and *italics* ``` . . . Code ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/demo-code_ef12d6982fded203ab84580cb877d570'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) mtcars |> head() ``` ::: . . . LaTeX ``` bash $$ \sum_{i}^{n} x^{i} $$ ``` ::: footer ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ![](figs/quarto-fig.png){fig-align="center"} # Installing Packages ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Two main commands are used to manage packages in R: 1. Installation: ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/installation_8d121f39f74ae1f11f83a03b45b3b1b2'} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("pkgname") ``` ::: . . . 2. Loading the package: ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/loading_571e8f8ca36c584d08f7f4975541f12d'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(pkgname) ``` ::: # Getting Help ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/help_3c8e20f2b3ad4c3d756879da9c74915b'} ```{.r .cell-code} help(function) ?function help.search(“keyword”) ``` ::: # Important Syntax ## Creating Objects Anything that is created in `R` whether it is a vector, matrix, function, data, figures, strings (character), etc. can be *assigned* into an *object* using the `<-` operator: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/assign_8be84d8812f2717e9c2e5d7d268b2299'} ```{.r .cell-code} name <- "camilo" name ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "camilo" ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/assign-mode_ca55bc6fbde63147b0df86200873f40e'} ```{.r .cell-code} typeof(name) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ::: # Main Objects in R ## Vectors A *vector* is a concatenation of other objects of the same type. ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/vectors_cdd1bb4bbfdd272014e3361a7f92b65f'} ```{.r .cell-code} time <- c(34, 13, 65, 10) # <1> season <- c("dry", "semidry", "rainy") heights <- c(1.60, 1.63, 1.85 ,1.72) ``` ::: ## Matrices A *matrix* is an *array* of objects that are ordered in rows and columns ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/matrixes_2b768b81977645deb46df5ec5bc6d501'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2|3,4,4|6,7,8"} mx <- matrix( c(23, 58, 98, 54, 68, 74), nrow = 2, ncol = 3, byrow = FALSE, dimnames = list( rows = c("rw1", "rw2"), cols = c("cl1", "cl2", "cl3") ) ) mx ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` cols rows cl1 cl2 cl3 rw1 23 98 68 rw2 58 54 74 ``` ::: ::: ## Lists A *list* is a set of ordered *components* (objects with assignments) ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/lists_173b6f354771d253b78d048ee6495dac'} ```{.r .cell-code} student_info <- list(name = "Alejandro", exam = 5, quizzes = c(4,5,3.5,4.2)) student_info ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $name [1] "Alejandro" $exam [1] 5 $quizzes [1] 4.0 5.0 3.5 4.2 ``` ::: ::: # Managing Data ## Manually Generated Data The `seq()` function can be used to create a *sequence* of data: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/seq-data_ac652b643cd9c871db7c383dfcd52ad8'} ```{.r .cell-code} data <- seq(1,100,10) data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 11 21 31 41 51 61 71 81 91 ``` ::: ::: . . . The `rep()` function creates *repetitions* of an object $n$ times ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/rep-data_ea28327b65dd478b3acfb885f22f99bc'} ```{.r .cell-code} data <- rep("Ho", 3) data ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Ho" "Ho" "Ho" ``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ You can also generate factors/levels using the `gl()` function. ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/gl-data-ex_ce808664ee68f67d7d5f7847ccebedc4'} ```{.r .cell-code} gl( n, # levels k, # replications length = n * k, labels = c("contro", "treatment"), ordered = FALSE ) ``` ::: let's try an example: . . . ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/gl-data_db5baba6a107e89389811da870d76098'} ```{.r .cell-code} ## First control, then treatment: #| output-location: fragment experiment <- gl(2, 8, labels = c("Control", "Treat")) experiment ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Control Control Control Control Control Control Control Control Treat [10] Treat Treat Treat Treat Treat Treat Treat Levels: Control Treat ``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ The `data.frame` object is a native structure/object to store table like data ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/df-intro-02_5565693b22d8d438455376c529ae619a'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1,2|4|6"} size <- c(34,50,40) color <- c("blue", "red", "orange") frogs <- data.frame(size, color) frogs ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Importing Data There are many function to *import* data to the `R` session. `read.table()` is one of the basic ones: *** ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/read-table_2dcaf23930629ee682a339a2efe55c29'} ```{.r .cell-code} spp_data <- read.table( file = "data/especies.txt", sep = "\t", h = TRUE ) spp_data ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: *** We can select subsets of the data set using many strategies. . . . 1. The `$` operator for column subseting: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/dollar-op_9347e898f7bf68b670acceb269cdffe6'} ```{.r .cell-code} spp_data$Especie ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" [5] "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" [9] "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" [13] "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" [17] "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" [21] "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" [25] "S_phaeota" ``` ::: ::: *** 2. The indexed way: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/index-sub_6076e358deea656ad7013d621b00ea28'} ```{.r .cell-code} spp_data[,2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" [5] "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" [9] "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" [13] "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" "C_fitzingeri" [17] "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" "S_phaeota" [21] "C_fitzingeri" "D_ebraccatus" "E_pustulosus" "O_histrionica" [25] "S_phaeota" ``` ::: ::: *** 3. Using a `subset()` and a condition: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/subset-table_e2f7e7556d40a8b23d9678ca2f8c0814'} ```{.r .cell-code} subset(spp_data, Prob_presencia > 0) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: # Common Operations *** ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/operation-table_ba1c1418835259ddba778e7735b95bae'} ```{.r .cell-code} 85+12 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 97 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 56-29 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 27 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 8*8 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 64 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 70/100 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.7 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} 2^4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16 ``` ::: ::: *** Importance of precedence ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/expression-01-table_41a2568e72668c063df16b88335aa718'} ```{.r .cell-code} 2+3*2-2^3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/expression-02-table_a057f2b8cc32493aed5643cf3b30caac'} ```{.r .cell-code} ((2+3)*2-2)^3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 512 ``` ::: ::: *** Operations with *vectors*: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/df-intro_05a5e3d21ad754ab3a63314071c211cb'} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|3"} time <- c(34, 13, 65, 10) time + 5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 39 18 70 15 ``` ::: ::: . . . What if you want to add another value to the vector: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/vector-add_aa44bacf40fc6008a6473611d1c332f6'} ```{.r .cell-code} time[5] = 5 time ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 34 13 65 10 5 ``` ::: ::: . . . So, the vector is now bigger: ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/vector-length_c026af8e2d5b48b505ad13ca2ea0cd97'} ```{.r .cell-code} length(time) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5 ``` ::: ::: # Descriptive Stats *** The simplest way to generate descriptive stats of a dataset is using `summary()` function. ::: {.cell output-location='fragment' hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/summary-length_eae3271a8754a1df36ef69f0a2b83c7f'} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(spp_data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Zona Especie Prob_presencia variacion Min. :1 Length:25 Min. :0.01996 Min. :11.00 1st Qu.:2 Class :character 1st Qu.:0.27549 1st Qu.:33.00 Median :3 Mode :character Median :0.42008 Median :59.00 Mean :3 Mean :0.46289 Mean :52.57 3rd Qu.:4 3rd Qu.:0.65240 3rd Qu.:72.50 Max. :5 Max. :0.92721 Max. :89.00 NA's :1 NA's :2 ``` ::: ::: # Inspecting Data *** [![From Data to Viz](figs/data-to-vis.png)](https://www.data-to-viz.com/index.html) *** Let's create an histogram, using base `hist()` function: ::: {.cell hash='01-introduction_cache/revealjs/unnamed-chunk-27_bcfe6f435159e0f22f6843ea47434b8f'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-introduction_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=960} ::: :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
